content:
ListBox.IntegerCollection Class

Definition

Represents a collection of integers in a ListBox.

In this Article

public class ListBox.IntegerCollection : System.Collections.IList
Inheritance
System.Object
ListBox.IntegerCollection

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
Equals(Object,Object)
GetHashCode()
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
ToString()

Remarks

ListBox.IntegerCollection is a sorted collection to which items are appended by using the Add and AddRange methods. Duplicate values are removed.

The ListBox.IntegerCollection is used mainly by the CustomTabOffsets property.

Constructors

ListBox.IntegerCollection(ListBox)

Initializes a new instance of the ListBox.IntegerCollection class.

public IntegerCollection (System.Windows.Forms.ListBox owner);
owner
ListBox

The ListBox that owns the collection.

Remarks

You cannot create an instance of the ListBox.IntegerCollection class without associating it with a ListBox control.

Properties

Count

Gets the number of selected items in the ListBox.

public int Count { get; }
Value
Int32

The number of selected items in the ListBox.

Remarks

Use the Count property to determine the number of selected items in the ListBox.IntegerCollection. You can then use this value when you are looping through the items and you need to provide a number of iterations to perform the loop.

Item(Int32)

Gets or sets the Item having the specified index.

public int this[int index] { get; set; }
index
Int32

The position of the Item in the collection.

Value
Int32

The selected Item at the specified position.

Methods

Add(Int32)

Adds a unique integer to the collection in sorted order.

public int Add (int item);
item
Int32

The integer to add to the collection.

Returns
Int32

The index of the added item.

Exceptions
SystemException

There is insufficient space available to store the new item.

AddRange(Int32[])

Adds an array of integers to the collection.

public void AddRange (int[] items);
items
Int32[]

The array of integers to add to the collection.

Remarks

The array of integers is appended to the collection, and duplicates are removed from the collection.

AddRange(ListBox+IntegerCollection)

Adds the contents of an existing ListBox.IntegerCollection to another collection.

public void AddRange (System.Windows.Forms.ListBox.IntegerCollection value);
value

The ListBox.IntegerCollection to add to another collection.

Remarks

The contents of the existing ListBox.IntegerCollection are appended to the current collection, and duplicates are removed from the combined collection.

Clear()

Removes all integers from the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

public void Clear ();

Contains(Int32)

Determines whether the specified integer is in the collection.

public bool Contains (int item);
item
Int32

The integer to search for in the collection.

Returns
Boolean

true if the specified integer is in the collection; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Use the Contains method to determine whether an integer is a member of the ListBox.IntegerCollection. Once you know that the item is located within the collection, you can use the IndexOf method to determine where the item is located within the collection.

CopyTo(Array,Int32)

Copies the entire ListBox.IntegerCollection into an existing array of integers at a specified location within the array.

public void CopyTo (Array destination, int index);
destination
Array

The array into which the ListBox.IntegerCollection is copied.

index
Int32

The location within the destination array to which to copy the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

Remarks

Use the CopyTo method to combine the integers from multiple collections into a single array. You can then use this array to populate the contents of another ListBox control using the AddRange method.

IndexOf(Int32)

Retrieves the index within the ListBox.IntegerCollection of the specified integer.

public int IndexOf (int item);
item
Int32

The integer for which to retrieve the index.

Returns
Int32

The zero-based index of the integer in the ListBox.IntegerCollection; otherwise, negative one (-1).

Remarks

Use the IndexOf method to determine where an item is located within the collection. To determine whether an item is located within the collection before calling this method, use the Contains method.

Remove(Int32)

Removes the specified integer from the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

public void Remove (int item);
item
Int32

The integer to remove from the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

Remarks

When you remove an integer from the ListBox.IntegerCollection, the indexes change for subsequent integers in the collection. All information about the removed integer is deleted. You can use the Remove method to remove a specific item from the list by specifying the actual item to remove from the list. To specify the index of the integer to remove instead of the integer itself, use the RemoveAt method.

If the integer is not in the ListBox.IntegerCollection, this method does nothing.

RemoveAt(Int32)

Removes the integer at the specified index from the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

public void RemoveAt (int index);
index
Int32

The zero-based index of the integer to remove.

Remarks

When you remove an integer from the ListBox.IntegerCollection, the indexes change for subsequent integers in the collection. All information about the removed integer is deleted. You can use the RemoveAt method to remove a specific integer from the list by specifying the index of the integer to remove from the list. To specify the item to remove instead of the index to the item, use the Remove method.

Explicit Interface Implementations

ICollection.IsSynchronized

Gets a value indicating whether access to the collection is synchronized (thread safe).

bool System.Collections.ICollection.IsSynchronized { get; }
Returns
Boolean

true in all cases.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an ICollection interface.

ICollection.SyncRoot

Gets an object that can be used to synchronize access to the collection of controls.

object System.Collections.ICollection.SyncRoot { get; }
Returns
System.Object

The object used to synchronize to the collection.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an ICollection interface.

IEnumerable.GetEnumerator()

Retrieves an enumeration of all the integers in the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

System.Collections.IEnumerator IEnumerable.GetEnumerator ();
Returns
IEnumerator

An IEnumerator for the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

Remarks

This method creates an enumerator that contains a snapshot of the collection. You can change the collection by changing the enumerator; however, multiple enumerators can simultaneously access the same collection. Changing the collection (either directly or through another enumerator) can thus cause Current or MoveNext to throw an exception.

Two enumerators created from the same collection at the same time can contain different snapshots.

Removing objects from the enumerator also removes them from the collection.

IList.Add(Object)

Adds a tab stop to the collection.

int IList.Add (object item);
item
System.Object

The tab stop to add to the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

Returns
Int32

The index at which the integer was added to the collection.

Exceptions
ArgumentNullException

item is null.

ArgumentException

item is not an 32-bit signed integer.

SystemException

There is insufficient space to store the new item in the collection.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

IList.Clear()

Clears all the tab stops from the collection.

void IList.Clear ();

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

IList.Contains(Object)

Determines whether the specified tab stop is in the collection.

bool IList.Contains (object item);
item
System.Object

The tab stop to locate in the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

Returns
Boolean

true if item is an integer located in the IntegerCollection; otherwise, false.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

IList.IndexOf(Object)

Returns the index of the specified tab stop in the collection.

int IList.IndexOf (object item);
item
System.Object

The tab stop to locate in the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

Returns
Int32

The zero-based index of item if it was found in the ListBox.IntegerCollection; otherwise, -1.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

IList.Insert(Int32,Object)

Inserts an item into the collection at a specified index.

void IList.Insert (int index, object value);
index
Int32

The zero-based index at which value should be inserted.

value
System.Object

The object to insert into the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

Exceptions
NotSupportedException

Always thrown.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

IList.IsFixedSize

Gets a value indicating whether the collection has a fixed size.

bool System.Collections.IList.IsFixedSize { get; }
Returns
Boolean

true in all cases.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

IList.IsReadOnly

Gets a value indicating whether the collection is read-only.

bool System.Collections.IList.IsReadOnly { get; }
Returns
Boolean

false in all cases.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

IList.Item(Int32)

Gets or sets the tab stop at the specified index.

object System.Collections.IList.Item[int index] { get; set; }
index
Int32

The zero-based index that specifies which tab stop to get.

Returns
System.Object

The tab stop that is stored at the specified location in the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

Exceptions
ArgumentException

The object is not an integer.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

IList.Remove(Object)

Removes the first occurrence of an item from the collection.

void IList.Remove (object value);
value
System.Object

The object to add to the ListBox.IntegerCollection.

Exceptions
NotSupportedException

Always thrown.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.

IList.RemoveAt(Int32)

Removes the item at a specified index.

void IList.RemoveAt (int index);
index
Int32

The index of the item to remove.

Exceptions
NotSupportedException

Always thrown.

Remarks

This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the ListBox.IntegerCollection instance is cast to an IList interface.
